name: Matcha Swiss Roll (Roll Cake)
description: Matcha Swiss Roll is a fluffy sponge cake with a swirl of fresh matcha cream filling. Light, creamy, and mildly sweet, it‚Äòs a delicious afternoon snack or post-dinner dessert to enjoy with coffee or tea. With its festive vibrant color from the green tea powder, this roll cake will be an instant favorite for any celebration, too.

video.description:
Fluffy sponge cake rolled up with fresh matcha cream in the middle, this Matcha (ÊäπËå∂) Swiss Roll will be an instant favorite this holiday season!

PRINT RECIPE ‚ñ∂ http://bit.ly/MatchaSwissRoll

Prep Time: 90 mins
Cook Time: 12 mins
Total Time: 102 minutes + 30 min cooling + 2 hour chilling

Serves: 1 10" (25 cm) Swiss roll
 
Ingredients:

4 large eggs (separated)
¬æ cup unbleached cake flour (90 g; *updated from the original 110 g in the video)
¬Ω tsp baking powder
2 Tbsp matcha (green tea powder)
¬Ω cup granulated sugar (¬Ω cup = 110 g) (separated)
3 Tbsp whole milk (microwave until warm to the touch) - SO SORRY for the caption error!

Matcha cream filling:
¬æ cup heavy cream or heavy whipping cream (¬æ cup = 180 ml) (chilled)
1 ¬Ω Tbsp granulated sugar
2 tsp matcha (green tea powder)

Instructions with step-by-step pics ‚ñ∂ http://bit.ly/MatchaSwissRoll

recipeIngredient: 4  large eggs (50 g each w/o shell)
2 Tbsp matcha (green tea powder) ((1 Tbsp matcha is 6 g))
3 Tbsp whole milk ((microwave until warm to the touch))

recipeInstructions.text: Before You Start: Please note that this recipe requires 30 minutes of resting time and 2 hours of chilling time.
recipeInstructions.name: Before You Start: Please note that this recipe requires 30 minutes of resting time and 2 hours of chilling time.

recipeInstructions.text: Gather all the ingredients. I highly encourage you to weigh your ingredients using a kitchen scale for this recipe. Click on the ‚ÄúMetric‚Äú button at the top of the recipe to convert the ingredient measurements to metric. If you‚Äòre using a cup measurement, please follow the ‚Äúfluff and sprinkle‚Äú method: Fluff your flour with a spoon, sprinkle the flour into your measuring cup, and level it off. Otherwise, you may scoop more flour than you need.
recipeInstructions.name: Gather all the ingredients. I highly encourage you to weigh your ingredients using a kitchen scale for this recipe. Click on the ‚ÄúMetric‚Äú button at the top of the recipe to convert the ingredient measurements to metric. If you‚Äòre using a cup measurement, please follow the ‚Äúfluff and sprinkle‚Äú method: Fluff your flour with a spoon, sprinkle the flour into your measuring cup, and level it off. Otherwise, you may scoop more flour than you need.

recipeInstructions.text: Preheat the oven to 375¬∫F (190¬∫C). For a convection oven, reduce the cooking temperature by 25¬∫F (15¬∫C). Line a¬†15- x 10-inch (38- x 25-cm) jelly roll pan¬†with parchment paper.
recipeInstructions.name: Preheat the oven to 375¬∫F (190¬∫C). For a convection oven, reduce the cooking temperature by 25¬∫F (15¬∫C). Line a¬†15- x 10-inch (38- x 25-cm) jelly roll pan¬†with parchment paper.

recipeInstructions.text: Separate 4 large eggs (50 g each w/o shell) into egg yolks in one bowl and egg whites in another. Keep the whites in the refrigerator and the egg yolks at room temperature.
recipeInstructions.name: Separate 4 large eggs (50 g each w/o shell) into egg yolks in one bowl and egg whites in another. Keep the whites in the refrigerator and the egg yolks at room temperature.

itemListElement.text: Prepare a work surface with a sheet of parchment paper. To a fine-mesh sieve, add ¬æ cup cake flour, ¬Ω tsp baking powder, and 2 Tbsp matcha (green tea powder). Sift these dry ingredients onto the parchment paper.
itemListElement.name: Prepare a work surface with a sheet of parchment paper. To a fine-mesh sieve, add ¬æ cup cake flour, ¬Ω tsp baking powder, and 2 Tbsp matcha (green tea powder). Sift these dry ingredients onto the parchment paper.

itemListElement.text: Use the parchment paper to transfer the dry ingredients to a bowl. Repeat sifting and transferring the dry ingredients two more times (for a total of three times). Set aside. Tip: Matcha is a very fine powder that‚Äôs difficult to blend into a batter without clumping. Sifting the dry ingredients three times ensures that the matcha and flour are well blended with no lumps and that air is incorporated into the mixture so it making it easier to blend into the batter.
itemListElement.name: Use the parchment paper to transfer the dry ingredients to a bowl. Repeat sifting and transferring the dry ingredients two more times (for a total of three times). Set aside. Tip: Matcha is a very fine powder that‚Äôs difficult to blend into a batter without clumping. Sifting the dry ingredients three times ensures that the matcha and flour are well blended with no lumps and that air is incorporated into the mixture so it making it easier to blend into the batter.

itemListElement.text: In a large bowl, add the egg yolks and break them with a hand whisk.
itemListElement.name: In a large bowl, add the egg yolks and break them with a hand whisk.

itemListElement.text: Add half of the ¬Ω cup sugar and whisk until the egg mixture doubles in volume. When you lift the whisk into the air with some of the mixture on it, the mixture should fall back into the bowl in ribbons, which slowly disappear back into the mixture.
itemListElement.name: Add half of the ¬Ω cup sugar and whisk until the egg mixture doubles in volume. When you lift the whisk into the air with some of the mixture on it, the mixture should fall back into the bowl in ribbons, which slowly disappear back into the mixture.

itemListElement.text: Next, add the cold egg whites to a large, dry bowl. With an electric hand mixer (or stand mixer), beat the egg whites until foamy.
itemListElement.name: Next, add the cold egg whites to a large, dry bowl. With an electric hand mixer (or stand mixer), beat the egg whites until foamy.

itemListElement.text: Gradually add the remaining half of the sugar, one-third at a time, and beat until stiff peaks form and the egg whites are glossy.
itemListElement.name: Gradually add the remaining half of the sugar, one-third at a time, and beat until stiff peaks form and the egg whites are glossy.

itemListElement.text: Using a hand whisk, gently fold about one-third of the egg whites into the egg yolk mixture until well incorporated.
itemListElement.name: Using a hand whisk, gently fold about one-third of the egg whites into the egg yolk mixture until well incorporated.

itemListElement.text: Then, add the egg yolk mixture back into the bowl with remaining the egg whites. Gently fold in the egg whites with a silicone spatula until just incorporated. Tip: Rotate the bowl a quarter turn counterclockwise while you scoop up and fold the mixture onto itself clockwise.
itemListElement.name: Then, add the egg yolk mixture back into the bowl with remaining the egg whites. Gently fold in the egg whites with a silicone spatula until just incorporated. Tip: Rotate the bowl a quarter turn counterclockwise while you scoop up and fold the mixture onto itself clockwise.

itemListElement.text: Next, add the dry ingredients to the egg mixture.¬†Using the silicone spatula, fold in gently until just incorporated. Do not overmix. Tip: Adding the dry ingredients last avoids overmixing, which results in a dense (not fluffy) sponge.
itemListElement.name: Next, add the dry ingredients to the egg mixture.¬†Using the silicone spatula, fold in gently until just incorporated. Do not overmix. Tip: Adding the dry ingredients last avoids overmixing, which results in a dense (not fluffy) sponge.

itemListElement.text: Add 3 Tbsp whole milk (warmed) to the batter and fold it in until incorporated.
itemListElement.name: Add 3 Tbsp whole milk (warmed) to the batter and fold it in until incorporated.

itemListElement.text: Pour the batter into the prepared pan. Spread the batter evenly using an offset spatula or silicone pastry scraper.
itemListElement.name: Pour the batter into the prepared pan. Spread the batter evenly using an offset spatula or silicone pastry scraper.

itemListElement.text: Tap the jelly roll pan a few times on your working surface to remove any air pockets in the batter. Transfer the pan to the preheated oven and bake for 10‚Äì12 minutes, or until an inserted toothpick comes out clean and the top of cake springs back when touched. Tip: Do not overbake it or the cake will be too dry and break when you roll it.
itemListElement.name: Tap the jelly roll pan a few times on your working surface to remove any air pockets in the batter. Transfer the pan to the preheated oven and bake for 10‚Äì12 minutes, or until an inserted toothpick comes out clean and the top of cake springs back when touched. Tip: Do not overbake it or the cake will be too dry and break when you roll it.

itemListElement.text: Remove the pan from the oven and drop the pan on your working surface once to prevent the cake from shrinking.
itemListElement.name: Remove the pan from the oven and drop the pan on your working surface once to prevent the cake from shrinking.

recipeInstructions.name: To Remove the Cake from the Pan

itemListElement.text: While the pan is still hot, place a sheet of parchment paper across the surface of the cake. Place a baking sheet (or a cutting board) on top with the bottom of the pan against the paper.
itemListElement.name: While the pan is still hot, place a sheet of parchment paper across the surface of the cake. Place a baking sheet (or a cutting board) on top with the bottom of the pan against the paper.

itemListElement.text: Wearing oven mitts, hold the two baking sheets together with the cake sandwiched in between and flip them over. Using a knife or spatula, lift the jelly roll pan to reveal the cake.
itemListElement.name: Wearing oven mitts, hold the two baking sheets together with the cake sandwiched in between and flip them over. Using a knife or spatula, lift the jelly roll pan to reveal the cake.

itemListElement.text: Gently peel off the parchment paper attached to the cake. This side will be the exterior of the Swiss roll, so be gentle!
itemListElement.name: Gently peel off the parchment paper attached to the cake. This side will be the exterior of the Swiss roll, so be gentle!

itemListElement.text: Now, flip over the cake one more time: Place another ‚Äúprotective‚Äù sheet of parchment paper across the cake surface, then place a baking sheet on top with the bottom of the pan against the paper.
itemListElement.name: Now, flip over the cake one more time: Place another ‚Äúprotective‚Äù sheet of parchment paper across the cake surface, then place a baking sheet on top with the bottom of the pan against the paper.

itemListElement.text: Hold both baking sheets together and flip them over so the brown side of the cake is now facing up. Remove the top pan and parchment paper.
itemListElement.name: Hold both baking sheets together and flip them over so the brown side of the cake is now facing up. Remove the top pan and parchment paper.

itemListElement.text: Remove the bottom baking sheet and place the cake with its parchment paper on a work surface. Slicing at an angle, cut off ¬Ω inch (1.3 cm) of the cake from one of the short ends. This will help stabilize the Swiss roll when rolled up.
itemListElement.name: Remove the bottom baking sheet and place the cake with its parchment paper on a work surface. Slicing at an angle, cut off ¬Ω inch (1.3 cm) of the cake from one of the short ends. This will help stabilize the Swiss roll when rolled up.

itemListElement.text: While it‚Äòs still warm, roll the cake: Start at the other short end and use your hands to slowly roll up the cake together with its parchment paper, finishing at the angled end that you just sliced. Once the cake and paper are rolled up, transfer to a wire rack with the seam side down.
itemListElement.name: While it‚Äòs still warm, roll the cake: Start at the other short end and use your hands to slowly roll up the cake together with its parchment paper, finishing at the angled end that you just sliced. Once the cake and paper are rolled up, transfer to a wire rack with the seam side down.

itemListElement.text: Cover with a kitchen towel to keep it secure and let it cool completely until it reaches room temperature, about 30 minutes.
itemListElement.name: Cover with a kitchen towel to keep it secure and let it cool completely until it reaches room temperature, about 30 minutes.

recipeInstructions.name: To Prepare the Matcha Cream Filling

itemListElement.text: When the cake is completely cool, combine ¬æ cup heavy (whipping) cream, 1¬Ω Tbsp sugar, and 2 tsp matcha (green tea powder) in a large bowl.
itemListElement.name: When the cake is completely cool, combine ¬æ cup heavy (whipping) cream, 1¬Ω Tbsp sugar, and 2 tsp matcha (green tea powder) in a large bowl.

itemListElement.text: Beat with an electric hand mixer (or stand mixer) until firm and spreadable, so it won‚Äôt ooze out of the cake when you‚Äôre rolling it up.
itemListElement.name: Beat with an electric hand mixer (or stand mixer) until firm and spreadable, so it won‚Äôt ooze out of the cake when you‚Äôre rolling it up.

itemListElement.text: Transfer the Swiss roll to a flat surface and unroll the cake. It‚Äôs okay if the ends curl up a bit.
itemListElement.name: Transfer the Swiss roll to a flat surface and unroll the cake. It‚Äôs okay if the ends curl up a bit.

itemListElement.text: Using an offset spatula, spread the matcha cream filling evenly over the cake, leaving a ¬Ω-inch (1.3 cm) border on all sides. Tip: Spread slightly less filling toward the last one-third of the cake, as the cream will pile up toward the end when rolling up.
itemListElement.name: Using an offset spatula, spread the matcha cream filling evenly over the cake, leaving a ¬Ω-inch (1.3 cm) border on all sides. Tip: Spread slightly less filling toward the last one-third of the cake, as the cream will pile up toward the end when rolling up.

itemListElement.text: Carefully but tightly reroll the cake with the filling inside. End with the seam side on the bottom. Secure the cake by rolling it in the parchment paper and twisting it at both ends, like a candy wrapper. Refrigerate for at least 2 hours to firm up the cream.
itemListElement.name: Carefully but tightly reroll the cake with the filling inside. End with the seam side on the bottom. Secure the cake by rolling it in the parchment paper and twisting it at both ends, like a candy wrapper. Refrigerate for at least 2 hours to firm up the cream.

itemListElement.text: Remove and unwrap the Swiss roll. Slice off about ¬Ω inch (1.3 cm) of the cake on both ends to show off the beautiful swirls. Transfer it to your serving dish. Slice and serve.
itemListElement.name: Remove and unwrap the Swiss roll. Slice off about ¬Ω inch (1.3 cm) of the cake on both ends to show off the beautiful swirls. Transfer it to your serving dish. Slice and serve.

itemListElement.text: If you have leftovers, just rewrap the Swiss roll in plastic wrap and store in the refrigerator for up to 3 days.
itemListElement.name: If you have leftovers, just rewrap the Swiss roll in plastic wrap and store in the refrigerator for up to 3 days.

review.reviewBody: Cake filing is pretty good, but I don‚Äôt understand why the cake (sponge part) came out so dry after the 2 hrs in fridge? It‚Äôs not fluffy and moist at all. I carefully followed through all of your steps and did not over mix. I folded in the mixture part, baked 10 min, did everything in the recipe so I‚Äôm not sure why the cake it‚Äôs dry??

Great recipe!  I don‚Äôt have the right size pan but I have a 1/4 sheet pan, so I make a couple little steamed cakes with extra batter so I don‚Äôt overfill the pan. Don‚Äôt have matcha on hand so I subbed cocoa powder (equal amounts) and 1/4 tsp espresso powder.  I also add a pinch of salt.  2nd time making it and both times it turned out great!

It took me three tries to get the roll consistency just right but even the unsuccessful versions disappeared within minutes. It's delicious and super pretty. Chill and moist desserts are hard to beat.

When I use matcha powder for baking it loses the vivid green colour and ends up looking much more brown than in your pictures. How can I keep the matcha as bright green as possible when using it for baking and desserts? (I am always using ceremonial grade matcha and keeping it tightly sealed in the fridge.)
Hi Nami, thanks for the recipe. I was wondering i this swiss roll freezes well too? thanks.
